facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 670 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 670 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 132 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 132 of 1964.

facts.text: The appellant was in the service of the State of Madhya Pradesh as a District and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in the service of the State of Madhya Pradesh as a District and Sessions Judge.

facts.text: He was born on August 22, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: He was born on August 22, 1908 and would in the normal course have retired on completing

facts.text: He would in the normal course have retired on completing the age of 55 years in August 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and would in the normal course have retired on completing the age of 55 years in August 1963.

facts.text: On February 28, 1963, the Government of Madhya Pradesh issued a memorandum to all the Collectors in the State.

anchor.surface_text: But on February 28, 1963, the Government of Madhya Pradesh issued a memorandum to all the Collectors in the, State.

facts.text: Copy of this memorandum was also sent to the Registrar, High Court as well as the Finance Department and the Accountant General.

anchor.surface_text: Copy of this memorandum was also sent to the Registrar, High Court as well as the Finance Department and the Accountant General.

facts.text: The State Government have decided that the age of compulsory retirement of State Government servants should be raised to 58 years subject to exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of this memorandum is as follows The State Government have decided that the age of compulsory retirement

facts.text: Notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing paragraphs, the appointing authority may require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing paragraphs, the appointing authority may require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reasons the power will normally be exercised to weed out unsuitable employees after they have attained the age of 55 years.

facts.text: These orders will have effect from the 1st March, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: These orders will have effect from the 1st March, 1963. Necessary amendments to the State Civil Service Regulations will be issued in due course.

facts.text: In consequence of this memorandum, the appellant who would have otherwise retired in August 1963 continued in service.

anchor.surface_text: in consequence of this memorandum, the appellant who, would have otherwise retired in August 1963, continued in service.

facts.text: On September 11, 1963 the Government sent an order to the appellant to retire with effect from the afternoon of the 31st December, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1963 the Government sent an order to the appellant in the following terms In pursuance of the orders contained in General Administration Department memorandum No. 433-258-1 iii /63, dated the 28th February, 1963, the State Government have decided to retire you with effect from the afternoon of the 31st December, 1963.

facts.text: On November 29, 1963 a notification was issued by the Finance Department which was published in the Madhya Pradesh Gazette dated December 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On November 29, 1963 a notification was issued by the Finance Department which was published in the Madhya Pradesh Gazette dated December 6, 1963 in the following terms -

facts.text: The notification amended Fundamental Rules by inserting new Rule 56: The date of compulsory retirement of a Government servant, other than a Class IV employee, is the date on which he attains the age of 58 years.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power conferred by the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution, the Governor of Madhya Pradesh hereby directs that the following further amendments shall be made in the Fundamental Rules applicable to the State of Madhya Pradesh namely All Rules in Chapter IX of the said Rules regarding Compulsory Retirement shall be deleted and the following shall be inserted as a new Rule 56, namely - R. 56 -The date of compulsory retirement of a Government servant, other than a Class IV employee, is the date on which he attains the age of 58 years.

facts.text: The rule has come into effect from 1st March, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The rule has come into, effect from 1st March, 1963.

facts.text: This amendment to the Rules did not include that part of the fifth paragraph which gave power to the appointing authority to require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reason.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen that this amendment to the Rules did not include that part of the fifth paragraph which gave power to the appointing authority to require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Thereafter the appellant was retired.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant was retired.

facts.text: He then filed a writ petition on March 24, 1964 challenging the order retiring him.

anchor.surface_text: He then filed a writ petition on March 24, 1964 challenging the order retiring him.

facts.text: Petitioner's contention: the rule as it stood after the amendment of November 29, 1963 contained no provision reserving power in Government to retire a Government servant after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reason.

anchor.surface_text: His contention was two-fold, namely- 1 that the rule as it stood after the amendment of November 29, 1963, published in the Gazette of December 6, 1963, contained no provision reserving power in Government to retire a Government servant after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reason, and therefore the appellant could not be retired on December 31, 1963 in the face of the rules,

facts.text: Petitioner's contention: as the order of his retirement cast a stigma on him it amounted to his removal, and therefore action under Article 311 of the Constitution was necessary.

anchor.surface_text: and ii that as the order of his retirement cast a stigma on him it amounted to his removal, and therefore action under Article 311 of the Constitution was necessary, and that was admittedly not complied with.

facts.text: Respondent's case: the order in question cast no stigma on the appellant, and therefore no action under Art. 311 was necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The application was opposed on behalf of the State Government, and their case was- i that the order in question cast no stigma on the appellant, and therefore no action under Art. 311 was necessary,

facts.text: Respondent's case: the memorandum of February 28, 1963 was in itself a rule and therefore the appellant was rightly retired in view of paragraph 5 of that memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: ii that the memorandum of February 28, 1963 was in itself a rule and therefore the appellant was rightly retired in view of paragraph 5 of that memorandum

facts.text: High Court held that the memorandum of February 28, 1963 was in itself a rule under Art. 309 and therefore the appellant was rightly retired under that rule.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the order in question retiring the appellant cast no stigma on him. It further held that the memorandum of February 28, 1963 was in itself a rule under Art. 309 and therefore the appellant was rightly retired under that rule.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petition but granted a certificate to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court dismissed the petition, but granted a certificate to the appellant as prayed by him, and that is how the matter has come before us.

facts.text: The appellant attained the age of 58 years in August 1966.

anchor.surface_text: As however the appellant attained the age of 58 years, in August 1966,

facts.text: The Supreme Court allows the appeal, sets aside the order of the High Court and quashes the order of retirement passed in this case.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and quash the order of retirement passed in this case.

facts.text: The memorandum of February 28, 1963 was never published in the Gazette.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place the. Resolution was published in the Gazette of India while in the present case the memorandum which has been treated by the High Court as amounting to rules made under Art. 309, has never been published in the Gazette.

facts.text: Fundamental Rule 56, as it existed before March 1, 1963, provided 55 years as the age of retirement.

anchor.surface_text: Fundamental Rule 56, as it existed before March 1, 1963, provided 55 years as the age of retirement.

facts.text: It further provided that a Government servant might be retained in service after that date with the sanction of the local Government on public grounds which must be recorded in writing.

anchor.surface_text: It further provided that a Government servant might be retained in service after that date with the sanction of the local Government on public grounds which must be recorded in writing, but he must not be retained after the age of 60 years except in very special circumstances.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the memorandum of February 28, 1963 contains merely executive instructions.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the memorandum of February 28, 1963 does not amount to rules under Art. 309 it contains merely executive instructions,

facts.text: The order retiring the appellant does not expressly contain any words from which any stigma can be inferred.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we hold that as the order does not expressly contain any words from which any stigma can be inferred it cannot amount an order of removal.

facts.text: The appellant will be entitled to such benefits as may accrue to him by virtue of the success of the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: But he will be entitled to such benefits as may accrue to him by virtue of the success of the writ petition.

arguments.claim: Order of compulsory retirement amounts to removal if expressly casts stigma, citing Jagdish Mitter

anchor.surface_text: This Court has consistently held that where , the order directing compulsory retirement expressly contains words which cast a stigmaon a Government servant, the order is equivalent to an order of removal and action under Art. 311 is necessary.

arguments.claim: No precedent where compulsory retirement without express stigma words held as removal

anchor.surface_text: But we asked learned counsel for the appellant to point out any case of this Court where in the absence of any express words in the order itself casting stigma on a Government servant, this Court has held that the order of compulsory retirement amounts to removal.

arguments.claim: Cannot infer stigma by reading memorandum into order or delving into files

anchor.surface_text: We are not prepared to extend the decisions of this Court on this aspect of the matter in the manner contended for by the appellant. Where an order requiring a Government servant to retire compulsorily contains express words from which a stigma can be inferred, that order will amount to removal

arguments.claim: Paragraph 5 of memo has two parts; first gives power without reason, no stigma; second is direction to appointing authority

anchor.surface_text: Besides, Para 5 of the memorandum is obviously in two parts The first part lays down that notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing paragraphs, the appointing authority may require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months notice without assigning any reason. There is no stigma here.

arguments.claim: Mere compulsory retirement before superannuation not stigma requiring Art 311

anchor.surface_text: What the appellant wants us to hold is that the mere fact that a Government servant is compulsorily retired before he reaches the age of superannuation is in itself a stigma. But this is against the consistent view of the Court

arguments.claim: Memorandum not rule under Art 309: not published in Gazette unlike Shyam Lal resolution

anchor.surface_text: In the first place the. Resolution was published in the Gazette of India while in the present case the memorandum which has been treated by the High Court as amounting to rules made under Art. 309, has never been published in the Gazette.

arguments.claim: Memorandum form is executive letter, not rules; announces decision, says amendments to follow

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, it is only in the form of a letter to the Collectors with copies to the High Court, the Finance Department and the Accountant General. Secondly, the Resolution of November 15, 1919 in terms said that it was announcing certain new rules

arguments.claim: Actual rule form shown by Nov 29 notification; contrast with memo language

anchor.surface_text: The form in which a rule is issued under Art. 309 is clear from what happened on November 29, 1963 when the amendment was actually made. We have set out that already, and the contrast in the language would show that the latter was a rule while the former

arguments.claim: Omission of para 5 first part from new FR56 indicates memo was executive instruction

anchor.surface_text: If it was the intention of Government that the first part of para 5 of the memorandum should also form a part of the rule, we fail to see why that was not inserted as a separate, proviso or explanation to F.R. 56 when it was in terms amended on November 29, 1963

arguments.claim: Memorandum merely executive instructions under old FR56 allowing retention beyond 55 on public grounds

anchor.surface_text: Fundamental Rule 56, as it existed before March 1, 1963, provided 55 years as the age of retirement. It further provided that a Government servant might be retained in service after that date with the sanction of the local Government on public grounds

arguments.claim: General executive order retaining all up to 58 valid under old FR56 in public interest

anchor.surface_text: But we see nothing illegal if the Government came to the conclusion generally that services of all Government servants should be retained till the age of 58 in public interest. -In such a case a general order would be enough and no individual orders need be passed.

holdings.text: as the order does not expressly contain any words from which any stigma can be inferred it cannot amount an order of removal

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we hold that as the order does not expressly contain any words from which any stigma can be inferred it cannot amount an order of removal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents require express stigmatizing words in the order itself for it to amount to removal under Art. 311; cannot infer from referenced memorandum's explanatory note or secretariat files; para 5 of memo separates power grant (no stigma) from usage direction.

holdings.text: the memorandum of February 28, 1963 does not amount to rules under Art. 309 it contains merely executive instructions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not published in Gazette unlike precedents; issued as internal letter to Collectors not rule form; announces executive decision pending formal amendments to regulations; contrast with actual Art. 309 notification language; omission of para 5 power in formal rule confirms status.

holdings.text: the memorandum of February 28, 1963 is merely in the nature of such a general order of extension of service by Government under F.R. 56 as it existed on that date

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the memorandum of February , 28, 1963 is merely in the nature of such a general order of extension of service by Government under F.R. 56 as it existed on that date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Old FR 56 permitted retention beyond 55 on recorded public grounds; general executive order retaining all servants to 58 valid in public interest without individual orders; bridges to formal rule.

holdings.text: It is not necessary for us to decide whether a rule of this kind which was notified on December 6, 1963 could be made retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the rule said so. It is not necessary for us to decide whether a rule of this kind which was notified on December 6, 1963 could be made retrospectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as notification itself claims effect from March 1, 1963; memo independently justifies retention under old FR 56.

precedents.citation: Jagdish Mitter v. the Union of India.  1

anchor.surface_text: Jagdish Mitter v. the Union of India.  1  In that case the order was in these terms Shri Jagdish Mitter, a temporary 2nd Division Clerk of this office having been found undesirable to be retained in Government service is hereby served with a months notice of discharge with effect from November 1, 1949. It was held that when the order referred to the fact that Jagdish Mitter was found undesirable to be retained in Government Service, it expressly cast a stigma on him, and in that sense must be held to be an order of dismissal and not a mere order of discharge.

precedents.case_name: Jagdish Mitter v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: An order of discharge or compulsory retirement that expressly casts a stigma by stating the employee is undesirable to retain amounts to dismissal or removal requiring compliance with Article 311
precedents.cited_holding: when the order referred to the fact that Jagdish Mitter was found undesirable to be retained in Government Service, it expressly cast a stigma on him, and in that sense must be held to be an order of dismissal and not a mere order of discharge

precedents.citation: State Of U.P. v. M. M. Nagar.  2

anchor.surface_text: State Of U.P. v. M. M. Nagar.  2  There also the order in express terms contained words which cast a stigma on the Government servant who was compulsorily retired and it was held in those circumstances that the order was in fact an order of removal from service. This Court A.I.R. 1964. S. C. 449.  2  1967 2 S.C.R. 333. has consistently held that where , the order directing compulsory retirement expressly contains words which cast a stigmaon a Government servant, the order is equivalent to an order of removal and action under Art. 311 is necessary.

precedents.case_name: State of U.P. v M.M. Nagar
precedents.cited_proposition: Compulsory retirement order containing express words casting stigma amounts to removal from service
precedents.cited_holding: the order in express terms contained words which cast a stigma on the Government servant who was compulsorily retired and it was held in those circumstances that the order was in fact an order of removal from service

precedents.citation: Shyam Lai v. the State of U.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: Shyam Lai v. the State of U.P.  1  where a Resolution of November 15, 1919 was held to be a rule by this Court, though later that Resolution was incorporated in the Civil Service Regulations in June 1920, It is however clear that facts in that case with respect to the Resolution of November 15, 1919 were very different. In the first place the. Resolution was published in the Gazette of India while in the present case the memorandum which has been treated by the High Court as amounting to rules made under Art. 309, has never been published in the Gazette.

But he will be entitled to such benefits as may accrue to him by virtue of the success of the writ petition.
